proof:
Proof. Fix $\tau$. Let $h_t$ be the number of edges in $\text{HIGH}(\tau)$ that have arrived by time $t$.

Now, fix a position $i \in \{1, \dots, m\}$. At each time $t$, either no jump happens, or some edge jumps from position $t' > t$ to position $t$. Consider the first time $t^*$ an edge $e \in \text{LOW}(\tau)$ jumps over $i$. We want to show that $t^*$ cannot be “much smaller” than $i$. Assume this jump is from position $t' > i$ to position $t^* < i$. So, the position of $e$ at time $t^* - 1$ in the updated prediction is $t'$, i.e., $\text{index}_{t^*-1}(e) = t'$. Also, the actual position of $e$ is $t^*$, i.e., $\text{index}(e) = t^*$. We know that
$$ t' - t^* = \text{index}_{t^*-1}(e) - \text{index}(e) \le \tau + h_{t^*-1} \le \tau + |\text{HIGH}(\tau)|, $$
which means that $i - t^* < t' - t^* \le \tau + |\text{HIGH}(\tau)|$.

Before time $t^*$, all the edges that might have jumped over $i$ are in $\text{HIGH}(\tau)$. So there are at most $|\text{HIGH}(\tau)|$ jumps over $i$ before time $t^*$. Also, after time $i$, no edge can jump over $i$. Therefore, the total number of jumps over $i$ is at most $|\text{HIGH}(\tau)| + (i - t^* + 1) \le \tau + 2|\text{HIGH}(\tau)|$.
